name: palm fruit bunch production | palm fruit bunch | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/441/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of palm fruit bunch (fresh matter). The yield is 24978 kg/ha at a moisture content at storage of 47%.;;This activity was adapted to include specific land use change (LUC) emissions. See comment of"carbon dioxide, from soil or biomass stock" for details.

This activity assumes palm fruit bunch production on a plantation with a lifetime of 20 years and represents the average operation expenditures of the production of 1 kg of fresh fruit bunch averaged across the whole lifetime including establishment, operation and clearing of the plantation. The inputs of mineral fertilisers, pesticides and irrigation water are considered. The input of seed is considered neglectable compared to the plantation lifetime of 20 years. It is assumed that no organic fertilisers are applied.


The dataset includes all machine operations and corresponding machine infrastructure and sheds. Most operations are done by hand. Machine operations are: fertilisation, irrigation, weed control, pest and pathogen control, transport of harvested fruit bunches from field to farm (25 km) and clearing of the plantation (wood chopping). Further, direct field emissions are included. This activity ends after harvest and transport to the farm at the farm gate.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/012:Growing of perennial crops/0126:Growing of oleaginous fruits

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventory is modelled for Malaysia
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Machine usage is modelled with Malaysian processings and standard machinery processes. Emissions are calculated with standard methods.

exchanges.description:
Generic peat emission for Malaysia from the LUC model (integrated via the intermediate inpput "land ue change, perennial crop") are complemented with specific peat emissions for Malaysia obtained from the area of oil palm plantations on peatland reported in Page et al. (2011), p. 18. Annual mission factor of 106000 kg CO2/ha is multiplied with proportion of oil palm plantations on peat land 23% and devided by yield to related it to 1 kg of palm fruit bunch.
Page, S.E., Morrison, R., Malins, C., Hooijer, A., Rieley, J.O., Jauhiaainen, J., 2011. Review of peat surface greenhouse gas emissions from oil palm plantations in Southeast Asia (Whitepaper). International Council on Clean Transportation, Washington.

Calculated value. See the parameters and their comments to understand the calculation.

Calculated as the difference between heavy metal input through fertilisers and output through the harvested product. Heavy metal contents of fresh palm fruit bunch for copper (Cu) and zinc (Zn) according to Corley & Tinker (2003). Heavy metal contents of mineral fertilisers according to  Nemecek et al. (2004). Negative values represent a net export of heavy metals. For heavy metals other than Cu and Zn no data were available; uptake of heavy metals by palm fruit bunches was assumed to be 50% of the input through fertilisers. --- Sources: Nemecek T., Heil A., Huguenin O., Meier S., Erzinger S., Blaser S., Dux D. & Zimmerman A. (2004) Life Cycle Inventories of Agricultural Production Systems. Ecoinvent report no. 15. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Duebendorf, Switzerland.

(2004) Life Cycle Inventories of Agricultural Production Systems. Ecoinvent report no. 15. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Duebendorf, Switzerland.

Amount of nutrient is an average based on IFA (2006), Corley & Tinker (2003), Ng et al. (1999) and Hofstetter (2006); type of fertiliser product from IFA (2006). --- Sources: IFA (2006): World Fertilizer Use Manual. Retrieved 16 May 2006 from http://www.fertilzer.org/ifa. --- Corley R. & Tinker P. (Ed) (2003) The Oil Palm. World Agricultural Series. Blackwell Science, Oxford. --- Ng P.H.C., Chew P.S., Goh K.J. & Kee K.K. (1999) Nutrient requirements and sustainability in mature oil palms - an assessment. Planter, Kuala Lumpur 75, 331-345. --- Hofstetter P. (WWF Switzerland) personal communication, June 2006.

flow.name: Energy, gross calorific value, in biomass

exchanges.description: Modelled, see chapter 'Land use' in "01_crop production_direct field emissions and natural resources_v1.0.pdf" - pdf-document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation)

Where soil C is lost through oxidation as a result of land-use or management change, this loss will be accompanied by a simultaneous mineralisation of N. Where a loss of soil C occurs, this mineralised N is regarded as an additional source of N available for conversion to N2O. Modelled, based on "Guidlines_LUC_Calcs" -pdf- document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation). See Equation 11 for details. Note: the opposite process to mineralisation, whereby inorganic N is sequestered into newly formed SOM, is not taken account of in the calculation of the mineralisation N source. This is because of the different dynamics of SOM decomposition and formation, and also because reduced tillage in some circumstances can increase both SOM and N2O emission. The constant term in the mathematical relation represents the N2O emissions from agriculture regardless of the land use changes; it was calculated according to IPCC 2006, see chapter 'Emissions of N2O to the air' in "01_crop production_direct field emissions and natural resources_v1.0.pdf" - pdf-document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation).

flow.name: Dinitrogen monoxide
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Calculated value based on literature values and expert opinion. See comments in the parametres' comment field.
Calculated value. See the parameters and their comments to understand the calculation.

Total amount of active substance/s of fertilisers needed for the production of 'palm fruit bunch' is calculated to be circa 2.20E-02 kg. Fertiliser/s used in this dataset is/are: 'ammonium sulfate, as N', 'dolomite', 'lime', 'phosphate fertiliser, as P2O5', 'potassium chloride, as K2O'. The total amount of active substance/s is doubled in order to account for the packaging of the dilluted product of fertiliser/s that is/are applied. Therefore, 4.40E-02 kg of packaging for fertilisers is justified with this exchange.

(1999) and Hofstetter (2006); type of fertiliser product from IFA (2006). --- Sources: IFA (2006): World Fertilizer Use Manual. Retrieved 16 May 2006 from http://www.fertilzer.org/ifa. --- Corley R. & Tinker P. (Ed) (2003) The Oil Palm. World Agricultural Series. Blackwell Science, Oxford. --- Ng P.H.C., Chew P.S., Goh K.J. & Kee K.K. (1999) Nutrient requirements and sustainability in mature oil palms - an assessment. Planter, Kuala Lumpur 75, 331-345. --- Hofstetter P. (WWF Switzerland) personal communication, June 2006.
